location: Rome. An ante-chamber in OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.

lines.text: Enter AGRIPPA at one door, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS at another

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: What, are the brothers parted?

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: They have dispatch'd with Pompey, he is gone; The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps To part from Rome; Caesar is sad; and Lepidus, Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled With the green sickness.

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: A very fine one: O, how he loves Caesar!

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Caesar? Why, he's the Jupiter of men.

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Spake you of Caesar? How! the non-pareil!

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: O Antony! O thou Arabian bird!

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Would you praise Caesar, say 'Caesar:' go no further.

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony: Ho! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number, ho! His love to Antony. But as for Caesar, Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: Both he loves.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: They are his shards, and he their beetle. So; This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.
Trumpets within

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: Good fortune, worthy soldier; and farewell.
Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, MARK ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: No further, sir.

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: You take from me a great part of myself; Use me well in 't. Sister, prove such a wife As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony, Let not the piece of virtue, which is set Betwixt us as the cement of our love, To keep it builded, be the ram to batter The fortress of it; for better might we Have loved without this mean, if on both parts This be not cherish'd.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Make me not offended In your distrust.

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: I have said.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: You shall not find, Though you be therein curious, the least cause For what you seem to fear: so, the gods keep you, And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends! We will here part.

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well: The elements be kind to thee, and make Thy spirits all of comfort! fare thee well.

lines.speaker: octavia
lines.text: My noble brother!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: The April 's in her eyes: it is love's spring, And these the showers to bring it on. Be cheerful.

lines.speaker: octavia
lines.text: Sir, look well to my husband's house; and--

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: What, Octavia?

lines.speaker: octavia
lines.text: I'll tell you in your ear.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can Her heart inform her tongue,--the swan's down-feather, That stands upon the swell at full of tide, And neither way inclines.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  Will Caesar weep?

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  He has a cloud in 's face.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  He were the worse for that, were he a horse; So is he, being a man.

lines.speaker: agrippa
lines.text: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  Why, Enobarbus, When Antony found Julius Caesar dead, He cried almost to roaring; and he wept When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  That year, indeed, he was troubled with a rheum; What willingly he did confound he wail'd, Believe't, till I wept too.

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: No, sweet Octavia, You shall hear from me still; the time shall not Out-go my thinking on you.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Come, sir, come; I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love: Look, here I have you; thus I let you go, And give you to the gods.

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: Adieu; be happy!

lines.speaker: lepidus
lines.text: Let all the number of the stars give light To thy fair way!

lines.speaker: octavius caesar
lines.text: Farewell, fa rewell!
Kisses OCTAVIA

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Farewell!
Trumpets sound. Exeunt
